BinaryAnalysis::InstructionSemantics::BaseSemantics::MemoryCell

List of all members.

Detailed Description

template<template< size_t > class ValueType>
class BinaryAnalysis::InstructionSemantics::BaseSemantics::MemoryCell< ValueType >

Represents one location in memory.

Each memory cell has an address, data, and size in bytes. It also maintains two boolean values to track whether a cell has been clobbered by a possibly-aliasing write, and how the cell was initialized.

When a memory state is created, every memory location will be given a unique value. However, it's not practicle to store a value for every possible memory address, yet we want the following example to work correctly:

  1: mov eax, ds:[edx]    // first read returns V1
  2: mov eax, ds:[edx]    // subsequent reads from same address also return V1
  3: mov ds:[ecx], eax    // write to unknown address clobbers all memory
  4: mov eax, ds:[edx]    // read from same address as above returns V2
  5: mov eax, ds:[edx]    // subsequent reads from same address also return V2

Furthermore, in some semantic policies the read from ds:[edx] at #1 above, retroactively stores V1 in an original memory state. That way if it needs to do additional analyses starting from the same initial state it will be available to use. In other words, the first read from a memory location causes a memory cell to spring into existence in both the current state and the initial state.

To summarize: every memory address is given a unique named value. These values are implicit until the memory location is actually read.

See also readMemory() and writeMemory() methods in the various instruction semantics policies.

) [inline]

Constructor.

Creates a new memory cell object with specified address, data, and size. The clobbered and written properties are both initialized to false.

template<template< size_t > class ValueType>
bool BinaryAnalysis::InstructionSemantics::BaseSemantics::MemoryCell< ValueType >::is_clobbered (  )  const [inline]

Accessor for whether a cell has been clobbered.

A cell should be marked as clobbered when a new cell is created and the address of the new cell could be equal to the address of this cell.

template<template< size_t > class ValueType>
bool BinaryAnalysis::InstructionSemantics::BaseSemantics::MemoryCell< ValueType >::is_written (  )  const [inline]

Accessor for whether a cell has been written.

A cell that is written to with writeMemory() should be marked as such. This is to make a distinction between cells that have sprung insto existence by virtue of reading from a previously unknown cell and cells that have been created as a result of a memoryWrite operation.

Definition at line 225 of file BaseSemantics.h.

Definition at line 227 of file BaseSemantics.h.

template<template< size_t > class ValueType>
template<typename PrintHelper>
void BinaryAnalysis::InstructionSemantics::BaseSemantics::MemoryCell< ValueType >::print ( std::ostream &  o,
const std::string  prefix = "",
PrintHelper *  ph = NULL 
) const [inline]

Prints a memory cell.

The output (at least for the BaseSemantics::MemoryCell implementation) is three lines, one each for the address, the value, and various flags. Each line is prefixed with the specified prefix string. The print() method of the underlying ValueType should accept two arguments: the std::ostream and a pointer to an optional templatized PrintHelper which is not interpreted in any way by this method.

Definition at line 236 of file BaseSemantics.h.
